codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#CI_PresentationFormCode"                                                codeListValue="mapDigital">mapDigital</gmd:CI_PresentationFormCode>                </gmd:presentationForm>             </gmd:CI_Citation>          </gmd:citation>          <gmd:abstract>             <gco:CharacterString>The Bathymetric Shaded Relief of North America map layer shows depth ranges using colors, with relief enhanced by shading. The image was derived from the National Geophysical Data Center's ETOPO2 elevation data, which is an elevation database gridded at 2-minute resolution, containing elevation and bathymetry for the world. The image was produced from the October 2001 data set.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:abstract>          <gmd:purpose>             <gco:CharacterString>The bathymetric shaded relief image was developed to portray the underwater terrain of North America. The image is intended for visual purposes only. The original ETOPO2 data must be used for conducting analysis and determining specific bathymetric values.</gco:CharacterString>          </gmd:purpose>          <gmd:status>             <gmd:MD_ProgressCode codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/Codelist/gmxCodelists.xml#MD_ProgressCode"                                  codeListValue="completed">completed</gmd:MD_ProgressCode>          </gmd:status>          <gmd:pointOfContact>             <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>                <gmd:individualName>                   <gco:CharacterString>L.   <gmd:lineage>             <gmd:LI_Lineage>                <gmd:processStep>                   <gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                      <gmd:description>                         <gco:CharacterString>The ETOPO2 data set was downloaded from the National Geophysical Data Center web site using their GEODAS Grid Translator Design-a-Grid interface. This interface allows a user to create custom grids. Users can access the web interface at http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/gdas/gd_designagrid.html. The following grid parameters were used: >Grid Database: ETOPO2 2-minute Global Relief >Latitude/Longitude Area Bounds: 90\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'N to 90\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'S, 180\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'W to 180\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd0'E >Grid Cell Size: 2 minutes >Grid Cell Value Parameters: 2-byte integers, whole meters >Grid Format: ASCII raster format, Arc header The downloaded grid was converted to an ArcInfo grid using the ArcToolbox import-to-raster interface. ArcToolbox was also used to define the initial coordinate system as Geographic (Lat/Lon) with units in decimal degrees, and the datum as WGS 1984. East and west grids were derived from the main grid using the ArcInfo command GRIDCLIP. The east grid coverage was from 150 degrees to 180 degrees longitude and 0 degrees to 90 degrees latitude. The west grid coverage was from 0 degrees to -180 degrees longitude and 0 degrees to 90 degrees latitude. The ArcInfo command GRIDSHIFT was used to shift each grid 40 degrees east, moving all data into the Western hemisphere. This data processing step was necessary due to the inability of ArcInfo to project raster data across the 180-degree longitude line. The ArcInfo Grid command MERGE was used to combine the two grids into one grid. This grid was projected into the Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area projection, centered on 100 degrees West, 45 degrees North. The .prj file used in the Arc PROJECT command contained these parameters: > INPUT > PROJECTION GEOGRAPHIC > UNITS DD > PARAMETERS > OUTPUT > PROJECTION LAMBERT_AZIMUTHAL > UNITS METERS > XSHIFT 0.0 > YSHIFT 0.0 > PARAMETERS > 0.0 > -60 0 0 > 45 0 0 > 0.0 > 0.0 > END > Using a center of longitude of 60 degrees West in the projection parameters creates an actual center of 100 degrees West due to the grid shift of 40 degrees. After projecting the data, the ArcInfo command PROJECTDEFINE was used to reset the central meridian to 100 degrees West. The ArcInfo command GRIDCLIP was used to clip the grid to match the dimensions used for National Atlas of the United States data. The bathymetric color shaded relief image was created by combining two files. The first was a color image created by converting the depths from meters to feet, classifying the data into depth ranges, and then assigning an RGB color to each range, as shown below. >Depth Range Index Red Green Blue >From To >-28300 -16000 1 53 146 214 >-15999 -12000 2 87 159 220 >-11999 -9000 3 124 180 231 >-8999 -6000 4 146 194 237 >-5999 -3000 5 170 212 243 >-2999 -1500 6 186 219 247 >-1499 -750 7 200 228 251 >-749 20320 8 216 236 252 The lightest color tint (index 8) extended across the land area. The file was converted to TIFF format using the command GRIDIMAGE. Adobe Photoshop was used to convert this image from RGB to CMY (no black). The second file was a grayscale shaded relief rendition of the elevation data created with the ArcInfo Grid command HILLSHADE. The data were first filtered using a smoothing filter to lessen noise in the data. The HILLSHADE command was then performed using the following parameters: >azimuth = 315 degrees >altitude = 45 degrees >shade type = SHADE >vertical exaggeration = 5.0 The file was added as a black (K) band to the first file (CMY), to create a CMYK color shaded relief image. Overall contrast was enhanced and then, in Adobe Photoshop, the CMYK image was converted to RGB.</gco:CharacterString>                      </gmd:description>                      <gmd:dateTime>                         <gco:DateTime>2005-04-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>                      </gmd:dateTime>                      <gmd:source xlink:href="#NGDC - ETOPO2"/>                   </gmi:LE_ProcessStep>                </gmd:processStep>                <gmd:source>                   <gmd:LI_Source id="NGDC - ETOPO2">                      <gmd:description>
